title: End of school uniform rip-off: Crippling prices AGAINST THE LAW, says regulator
text:
End of school uniform rip-off: Crippling prices AGAINST THE LAW, says regulator End of school uniform rip-off: Crippling prices AGAINST THE LAW, says regulator SCHOOLS may have broken competition laws by charging parents outrageous prices for uniforms this September. PUBLISHED: 11:04, Fri, Oct 16, 2015 | UPDATED: 11:38, Fri, Oct 16, 2015 GETTY Parents have had to pay too much for uniform, according to the regulator 
Headteachers have been ordered to review their school uniform policies after crippling prices saw items up to £10 more expensive than comparable options. 
The mark-ups occurred where schools have appointed exclusive suppliers and banned pupils from wearing cheaper options, according to the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA). 
Those stringent policies are against the law, according to the watchdog. 
It has been inundated with complaints from parents concerned about prices and quality. 
Supermarkets have fought to offer parents low priced items, with items starting from around £2-£3 from the likes of Asda and Tesco. 
Sam Royston, director of policy at the Children's Society, said: "School uniform costs can be a millstone around the necks of poorer parents, contributing to a cycle of debt and damaging the opportunities and well-being of lower income pupils. 
"One reason for the high costs are policies that force parents to buy clothing from specialist shops, and prevent them from buying cheaper items from supermarkets." Related articles
